Award.AwardTitle: Structure and Functions of ER/Plasma Membrane Junctions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Endoplasmic reticulum/plasma membrane (ER/PM) junctions are known to be sites of calcium ion (Ca2+) influx. Recently, the PI discovered that these junctions function as trafficking hubs for insertion and removal of plasma membrane proteins. Furthermore, the PI has found that the voltage gated potassium channel Kv2.1 interacts with the endoplasmic reticulum, dramatically increasing ER/PM junction surface area and structurally changing the junction morphology. The PI's findings show that the Kv2.1 potassium channel remodels to cortical ER, which is likely within 30 nm of the plasma membrane. Kv2.1 is playing a structural role similar to that of Orai, for the PI proposes that Kv2.1 is binding an ER membrane protein. Thus, Kv2.1-mediated ER enrichment on the cell surface is a novel specialized organelle with specific functions in protein transport vital to cell signaling.

The current project focuses on understanding the biology of ER/PM junctions with particular emphasis on the regulation of the ER/PM junction structure and its function in the modulation of membrane protein trafficking. The PI will answer the following questions: What is the role of Kv2.1 in protein trafficking at ER/PM junctions? How are ER/PM junctions dynamically regulated by Kv2.1? What are the relationships between the cortical cytoskeleton, ER, and Kv2.1? Which theoretical framework can be used to describe the assembly and maintenance of these domains? How does large-scale membrane behavior emerge from the interactions between Kv2.1 and ER? The fusion of multicolor single-molecule tracking in living cells and advanced stochastic process analysis, which are integral to the project, will provide answer to these questions. This research will offer excellent opportunities for graduate and undergraduate student participation in interdisciplinary research through the collaboration between two laboratories with very different backgrounds. The research program will be integrated with an outreach component by developing a microscopy laboratory for students at a local elementary school. The goal of the outreach program is to foster scientific enquiry and to motivate students to appreciate science from an early age. This lab presents a unique opportunity to leverage integration of education and research, giving students access to hands-on practical learning.

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Cellular Dynamics and Function Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have studied processes that take place at the surface of the cell, namely the plasma membrane. We have shed new light on the scaffolding that supports this membrane. Our results have shown that this scaffolding, known as the cytoskeleton, has a fractal structure. Like a cauliflower whose branches look like tiny versions of the whole vegetable, fractal structures look the same at different scales. The fractal structure of the cyctoskeleton seems to play an important role in organizing the activity on the surface of the cell. In order to visualize how the cytoskeleton affects the membrane, we employed extremely high resolution imaging tools (specifically, photoactivatable localization microscopy or PALM superresolution) of the cytoskeleton of human cells while simultaneously tracking individual proteins on the cell membrane. Tracking individual molecules in the membrane is performed by tagging these molecules with fluorescent probes that allow visualizing the location of even a single molecule in real time. In this way, we were able to explore how the cytoskeleton influences the way proteins on a cell membrane move. We have found that the fractal nature of the cytoskeleton plays a key role in bringing and maintaining proteins together, effectively compartmentalizing the membrane over many different length scales.

Additionally we have shown that contacts between the endoplasmic reticulum (a network of membranous tubules within eukaryotic cells) and the plasma membrane (the surface of the cell) function as trafficking hubs for multiple membrane proteins and alter the overall dynamics within the plasma membrane. Our findings show that the a specific membrane protein (the Kv2.1 potassium channel) is one of the main players in controling the size and location of these important contacts in neuron cells.    

This research program was integrated with an outreach component by developing a microscopy laboratory for elementary school students. The goal of this outreach program was to foster scientific enquiry and to motivate students to appreciate science through hands-on experiments. We have developed a microscopy laboratory for fifth grade students at Olander School for Project Based Learning in Fort Collins, Colorado, and trained three teachers in microscopy activities. The acquired microscopes allow for transmission and reflected illumination. Students have been working with the microscopes in teams of two or three. Two of the acquired microscopes have cameras mounted on them so that the teacher can project an image on a screen. Activities that were performed in this laboratory include characterizing red blood cells, insects, dust, snow, and living organisms from the local creek. This lab presents a unique opportunity to  give students access to hands-on practical learning. 

Two graduate students and 12 undergraduate students were supported by this award. The students (including five individuals from underrepresented groups in science and technology) were involved in interdisciplinary research. Undergraduate students presented their results in poster or platform presentations at meetings including APS 4-Corner Meeting, APS March Meeting, Colorado Photonics Industry Association, the Biomedical Engineering Society Meeting, and American Society for Cell Biology.
